Article VII – Financial Arrangements  .  IFAD shall reimburse direct staff costs additional indirect costs , example , travel per diem services performed specific request IFAD , accordance financial arrangements agreed upon two parties . Article VIII – Final Provisions  .  Agreement shall enter force date signed duly authorized representatives IFAD .  .  Agreement may modified consent two parties accordance respective constitutional procedures .  .  Agreement may terminated mutual agreement , may denounced either party giving party six months ’ written notice . Notwithstanding expiry notice termination , two parties agree provisions Agreement shall remain full force extent         BASIC DOCUMENTS necessary permit orderly conclusion activity undertaken pursuant Agreement .  . Article II – Objectives principles   . objective Agreement strengthen cooperation AU Commission .   . furtherance objective , AU Commission shall cooperate matters arising field health connected activities commitments two Organizations , including promoting improving health , reducing avoidable mortality disability , preventing disease , countering potential threats health , making contributions towards ensuring high level health protection placing health core international development agenda fight poverty , protection environment , promotion social development , raising living working conditions .   . AU Commission reaffirm , accordance respective mandates , complementary commitments serve needs respective Member States partner countries appropriate means , including : ( ) helping development maintenance effective health interventions systems ; ( b ) engaging various actors stakeholders promoting health development forming collaborative associations aimed improving health delivering health-related interventions ; total well-being , ( c ) containing crises outbreaks disease , imparting knowledge skills ; ( ) drawing expertise resources respective organizations Member States add value efforts achieve coordination design implementation health health-related policies ; ( e ) forging harmonious relations avoiding duplication effort pursuing common goals .      AGREEMENT AU      . Cooperation Parties shall respect differences institutional operational arrangements governing action , core competencies comparative advantages order make collaboration field health complementary mutually reinforcing . Article III – Areas cooperation   . Cooperation AU Commission shall extend questions connected health related fields within competence Parties , including , necessary appropriate , : ( ) generating , collecting , processing disseminating authoritative information data use national administrations , professionals parties competence field health , respecting data protection requirements ; ( b ) developing methodologies tools health monitoring disease surveillance , analysing targeting action specific health health-related problems , assessing prioritizing health interventions , aiding health system development strengthening ; ( c ) promoting health-related research technological development , taking stock results , developing advice applications health health-related fields ; ( ) mobilizing , managing coordinating , appropriate , resources health interventions collaboration recognized actors field cooperating emergencies resulting civil strife , war natural catastrophes ; ( e ) seconding staff purpose mutual provision expertise .   . cooperation would involve expenditure , consultation shall take place view determining feasibility and/or manner meeting expenditure . Article IV – Priorities Without prejudice priorities AU Commission may take precedence areas emphasis Agreement subject results joint periodic reviews , priorities cooperation shall include :   . strengthening health system human resources capacity ;         BASIC DOCUMENTS   . promotion access prevention , treatment , care support communicable noncommunicable diseases , well including geographical financial access poor vulnerable populations ;   . development sound policies efficient systems geared towards sustainable health development , including alleviation poverty , effective preparedness response prioritized health scourges threats combining efforts help developing least developed countries ;   . development methodologies standards analysis reporting , provision advice responses , particular , malaria , HIV/AIDS , tuberculosis , emerging diseases antimicrobial resistance threats , respecting human rights affected afflictions ;   . strengthening communicable disease surveillance health monitoring networks establishment strategies emergency preparedness response epidemics ;   . development health collection dissemination data health status health policies systems , promoting evidence-based approaches . indicators Article V – Privileges immunities facilities Nothing Agreement may interpreted construed waiver modification privileges , immunities facilities AU Commission enjoy virtue international agreements national laws applicable organizations . Article VI – Exchange information   . South Centre World Health Organization Martin Khor Dr Margaret Chan ––––––––––       Framework Engagement Non-State Actors  OVERARCHING FRAMEWORK ENGAGEMENT NON-STATE ACTORS INTRODUCTION   . overarching framework engagement non-State actors policy operational procedures management engagement non-State actors apply engagements non-State actors levels Organization ,   whereas four specific policies operational procedures engagement limited application , respectively , nongovernmental organizations , private sector entities , philanthropic foundations academic institutions . ENGAGEMENT : RATIONALE , PRINCIPLES , BENEFITS RISKS Rationale  . directing coordinating authority global health line constitutional mandate . global health landscape become complex many respects ; among things , increase number players including non-State actors . engages non-State actors view significant role global health advancement promotion public health encourage non-State actors use activities protect promote public health .   . functions , set Article   Constitution , include : act directing coordinating authority international health work ; establish maintain effective collaboration diverse organizations ; promote cooperation among scientific professional groups contribute advancement health . Constitution mandates Health Assembly Executive Board , Director-General , enter specific engagements organizations .   shall , relation non-State actors , act conformity Constitution resolutions decisions Health Assembly , bearing mind United Nations General _________   See resolution WHA  .   (      ) .   Headquarters , regional offices country offices , entities established , well hosted partnerships . hosted partnerships Framework Engagement Non-State Actors apply , subject policy ’ engagement global health partnerships hosting arrangements ( resolution WHA  .   ) . Hosted , well external partnerships explained paragraph    .   Constitution , Articles    ,    ,       . –    –      BASIC DOCUMENTS Assembly Economic Social Council United Nations , applicable .   . ’ engagement non-State actors supports implementation Organization ’ policies recommendations decided governing bodies , well application ’ technical norms standards . effective engagement non-State actors global , regional country levels , also calls due diligence transparency measures applicable non-State actors framework . order able strengthen engagement non-State actors benefit interest global public health , needs simultaneously strengthen management associated potential risks . requires robust framework enables engagement serves also instrument identify risks , balancing expected benefits , protecting preserving ’ integrity , reputation public health mandate . Principles   . ’ engagement non-State actors guided following overarching principles . engagement must : ( ) demonstrate clear benefit public health ; ( b ) conform ’ Constitution , mandate General Programme Work  ( c ) respect  decision-making authority Member States set ’ Constitution ; intergovernmental nature ( ) support enhance , without compromising , scientific evidence-based approach underpins ’ work ; ( e ) protect undue influence , particular processes setting applying policies , norms standards ;   ( f ) compromise ’ integrity , independence , credibility reputation ; ( g ) effectively managed , including , possible avoiding conflict interest  forms risks ; _________   Policies , norms standard setting includes information gathering , preparation , elaboration decision normative text .   set paragraphs   –   .      FRAMEWORK ENGAGEMENT NON-STATE ACTORS    ( h ) conducted basis transparency , openness , inclusiveness , accountability , integrity mutual respect . Benefits engagement   . ’ engagement non-State actors bring important benefits global public health Organization fulfilment constitutional principles objectives , including directing coordinating role global health . Engagements range major , longer-term collaborations smaller , briefer interactions . Benefits arising engagement also include : ( ) contribution non-State actors work ( b ) influence non-State actors enhance impact global public health influence social , economic environmental determinants health ( c ) influence non-State actors ’ compliance ’ policies , norms standards ( ) additional resources non-State actors contribute ’ work ( e ) wider dissemination adherence non-State actors ’ policies , norms standards Risks engagement   . ’ engagement non-State actors involve risks need effectively managed , appropriate , avoided . Risks relate inter alia occurrence particular following : ( ) conflicts interest ; ( b ) undue improper influence exercised non-State actor ’ work , especially , limited , policies , norms standard setting ;   ( c ) negative impact ’ integrity , independence , credibility reputation ; public health mandate ; ( ) engagement primarily used serve interests non-State actor concerned limited benefits public health ; _________   Policies , norms standard setting includes information gathering , preparation , elaboration decision normative text .          BASIC DOCUMENTS ( e ) engagement conferring endorsement non-State actor ’ name , brand , product , views activity ;   ( f ) whitewashing non-State actor ’ image engagement ; ( g ) competitive advantage non-State actor . NON-STATE ACTORS purpose framework , non-State actors   . nongovernmental organizations , private sector entities , philanthropic foundations academic institutions .    . Nongovernmental organizations non-profit entities operate independently governments . usually membership-based , non-profit entities individuals members exercising voting rights relation policies nongovernmental organization , otherwise constituted non-profit , public-interest goals . free concerns primarily private , commercial profit-making nature . could include , example , grassroots community organizations , civil society groups networks , faith-based organizations , professional groups , disease-specific groups , patient groups .    . Private sector entities commercial enterprises , say businesses intended make profit owners . term also refers entities represent , governed controlled , private sector entities . group includes ( limited ) business associations representing commercial enterprises , entities “ arm ’ length ”   commercial sponsors , partially fully State-owned commercial enterprises acting like private sector entities . International business associations private sector entities intend make profit represent interests members , commercial enterprises and/or national business associations . purposes framework , shall authority speak members authorized representatives . members shall exercise voting rights relation policies international business association . _________   Endorsement include established processes prequalifications Pesticide Evaluation Scheme ( WHOPES ) .   entity “ arm ’ length ” another entity independent entity , take instructions clearly influenced clearly reasonably perceived influenced decisions work entity .      FRAMEWORK ENGAGEMENT NON-STATE ACTORS        . Philanthropic foundations non-profit entities whose assets provided donors whose income spent socially useful purposes . shall clearly independent private sector entity governance decision-making .    . Academic institutions entities engaged pursuit dissemination knowledge research , education training.     . four groups entities , overarching framework respective specific policy engagement apply . determine due diligence non-State actor subject influence private sector entities extent non-State actor considered private sector entity . influence exerted financing , participation decision making otherwise . Provided decision-making processes bodies non-State actor remain independent undue influence private sector , decide consider entity nongovernmental organization , philanthropic foundation academic institution , may apply relevant provisions ’ policy operational procedures engagement private sector entities , accepting financial in-kind contributions use normative work . TYPES INTERACTION    . following categories interaction engages non-State actors . type interaction take different forms , subject different levels risk involve different levels types engagement Organization . Participation    . Non-State actors may attend various types meetings organized . nature participation depends type meeting concerned . format , modalities , participation non-State actors consultations , hearings , meetings decided case-by-case basis governing bodies Secretariat . ( ) Meetings governing bodies . type involves sessions World Health Assembly , Executive Board six regional committees . Non-State actors ’ participation determined governing bodies ’ respective rules procedure , policies practices well section framework deals official relations . _________   include think tanks policy-oriented institutions , long primarily perform institutions considered nongovernmental research ; international associations academic organizations , subject paragraph    .          BASIC DOCUMENTS ( b ) Consultations . type includes physical virtual meeting , governing body sessions , organized purpose exchanging information views . Inputs received non-State actors shall made publicly available , wherever possible . ( c ) Hearings . meetings participants present evidence , views positions questioned enter debate . Hearings electronic person . interested entities invited basis . participants positions presented hearings shall documented shall made publicly available , wherever possible . ( ) meetings . meetings part process setting policies , norms standards ; examples include information  meetings , briefings , scientific conferences , platforms coordination actors .    . ’ involvement meetings organized wholly partly non-State actor – subject provisions framework , four specific policies operational procedures , applicable rules , policies procedures – consist one following possibilities : • jointly organizes meeting non-State actor • cosponsors meeting  organized non-State actor • staff make presentation act panellists meeting organized non-State actor • staff attend meeting organized non-State actor . Resources    . Resources financial in-kind contributions . In-kind contributions include donations medicines goods free provision services  contractual basis . Evidence    . purposes framework , evidence refers inputs based up-to-date information , knowledge technical issues , consideration scientific facts , independently analysed . Evidence generation _________   Cosponsorship meeting means : (   ) another entity primary responsibility organizing meeting ; (   ) supports contributes meeting proceedings ; (   ) reserves right clear agenda meeting , list participants outcome documents meeting .   exception secondments , covered paragraph    .      FRAMEWORK ENGAGEMENT NON-STATE ACTORS     includes information gathering , analysis , generation information management knowledge research . Non-State actors may provide up-to-date information knowledge technical issues , share experience , appropriate , subject provisions framework , four specific policies operational procedures , applicable rules , policies procedures . contribution made publicly available , appropriate , wherever possible . Scientific evidence generated made publicly available . Advocacy    . Advocacy action increase awareness health issues , including issues receive insufficient attention ; change behaviours interest public health ; foster collaboration greater coherence non-State actors joint action required . Technical collaboration    . purpose framework , technical collaboration refers collaboration non-State actors , appropriate , activities fall within General Programme Work , including : • product development • capacity-building • operational collaboration emergencies • contributing implementation ’ policies . MANAGEMENT CONFLICT INTEREST RISKS ENGAGEMENT    . Managing , including , appropriate , avoiding , conflict interest risks engagement requires series steps , set below:  • needs know non-State actors engages . Therefore non-State actor required provide relevant  information activities , following conducts necessary due diligence . _________   framework designed regulate institutional engagements ; implementation closely coordinated implementation organizational policies regulating conflict interest respect individuals ( see paragraph    ) .   defined paragraph    .          BASIC DOCUMENTS • conducts risk assessment order identify specific risks engagement associated engagement non-State actor . • Risks engagement need managed communicated coherently three levels Organization throughout Organization . end , manages engagement single , Organization-wide electronic tool.  • Member States exercise oversight ’ engagement non- State actors accordance provisions paragraphs       . Conflict interest    . conflict interest arises circumstances potential secondary interest ( vested interest outcome ’ work given area ) unduly influence , may reasonably perceived unduly influence , either independence objectivity professional judgement actions regarding primary interest ( ’ work ) existence conflict interest forms mean improper action occurred , rather risk improper action occurring . Conflicts interest financial , take forms well .   .Individual conflicts interests within involving experts , regardless status , staff members ; addressed accordance policies listed paragraph    present framework .    . institutions multiple interests , means engaging non-State actors often faced combination converging conflicting interests . institutional conflict interest situation ’ primary interest reflected Constitution may unduly influenced conflicting interest non-State actor way affects , may reasonably perceived affect , independence objectivity ’ work .    . actively managing institutional conflict interest risks engagement mentioned paragraph   , aims avoid allowing conflicting interests non-State actor exert , _________   uses electronic tool managing engagement . described footnote   paragraph    , publicly visible part tool register non-State actors ; tool also provides electronic workflow internal management engagement . similar electronic tool used management individual conflicts interest , order harmonize implementation framework implementation policy management individual conflicts interest experts . FRAMEWORK ENGAGEMENT NON-STATE ACTORS     reasonably perceived exert , undue influence Organization ’ decision-making process prevail interests .    . , potential risk institutional conflicts interest could highest situations interest non-State actors , particular economic , commercial financial , conflict ’ public health policies , constitutional mandate interests , particular Organization ’ independence impartiality setting policies , norms standards . Due diligence risk assessment    . possibility entering engagement considered , relevant technical unit Secretariat conducts initial examination order establish whether engagement would interest Organization line principles ’ engagement non-State actors paragraph   priorities defined General Programme Work Programme budget . seems case , technical unit consults Register non-State actors needed asks non-State actor provide basic information . Using Organization-wide electronic tool , unit complements information description proposed engagement assessment benefits risks involved , needed .    . technical unit makes initial assessment . engagement low risk , example repetitive nature  involve policies , norms standard setting , simplified due diligence risk assessment modulating procedures paragraphs   –   well    performed technical unit risk management decision taken , taking steps necessary ensure full compliance paragraphs  – .  engagements full procedures apply .    . engaging non-State actor , , order preserve integrity , conducts due diligence risk assessment . Due diligence refers steps taken find verify relevant information non-State actor reach clear understanding profile . due diligence refers nature non-State actor concerned , risk assessment refers assessment specific proposed engagement non-State actor . _________   Provided due diligence risk assessment already carried nature engagement remained unchanged .   simplified due diligence risk assessment , information provided non-State actors well criteria low risk engagements described guide staff .          BASIC DOCUMENTS    . Due diligence combines review information provided non-State actor , search information entity concerned sources , analysis information obtained . includes screening different public , legal commercial sources information , including : media ; entity ’ website companies ’ analyst reports , directories profiles ; public , legal governmental sources .    . core functions due diligence : • clarify nature purpose entity proposed engage ; • clarify interest objectives entity engaging expects return ; • determine entity ’ legal status , area activities , membership , governance , sources funding , constitution , statutes , by-laws affiliation ; • define main elements history activities entity terms issues ; environmental , ethical business issues ; reputation image ; financial stability ; following : health , human labour • identify paragraph       applied .    . Due diligence also allows Secretariat purpose engagement categorize non-State actor relation one four groups non-State actors basis nature , objectives , governance , funding , independence membership . categorization indicated register non-State actors .    . Risks expression likelihood potential impact event would affect Organization ’ ability achieve objectives . risk assessment proposed engagement conducted addition due diligence . involves assessment risks associated engagement non-State actor , particular risks described paragraph   conducted without prejudice type non-State actor . Risk management    . FRAMEWORK ENGAGEMENT NON-STATE ACTORS     OFFICIAL RELATIONS    . “ Official relations ” privilege Executive Board may grant nongovernmental organizations , international business associations philanthropic foundations continue sustained systematic engagement  interest Organization . aims activities entities shall conformity spirit , purposes principles ’ Constitution , shall contribute significantly advancement public health . Organizations official relations attend governing body meetings otherwise subject rules non-State actors engaging .    . Entities official relations international membership and/or scope . entities official relations shall constitution similar basic document , established headquarters , governing body , administrative structure , regularly updated entry register non-State actors .    . Official relations shall based plan collaboration entity agreed objectives outlining activities coming three-year period structured accordance General Programme Work Programme budget consistent framework . plan shall also published register non-State actors . organizations shall provide annually short report progress made implementing plan collaboration related activities also published register . plans shall free concerns primarily commercial profit-making nature .    . nongovernmental organizations working global health issues , sustained systematic engagement could include research active advocacy around meetings ’ policies , norms standards . Executive Board shall responsible deciding admission organizations official relations shall review status every three years . Board may discontinue official relations considers relations longer appropriate necessary light changing programmes circumstances . FRAMEWORK ENGAGEMENT NON-STATE ACTORS     NON-COMPLIANCE FRAMEWORK    . Non-compliance include inter alia following : significant delays provision information register non-State actors ; provision wrong information ; use engagement purposes protecting promoting public health , commercial , promotional , marketing advertisement purposes ; misuse ’ name emblem ; attempt undue influence ; abuse privileges conferred official relations .    . Non-compliance non-State actor provisions framework consequences entity concerned due process including reminder , warning , cease-and-desist letter , rejection renewal engagement termination engagement . review status official relations Executive Board anticipated non-compliance reason non-renewal official relations . Except case important intentional cases non-compliance non-State actor concerned automatically excluded engagements .    . financial contribution received subsequently discovered non-compliant terms framework shall returned contributor . IMPLEMENTATION    . Consistent principles identified paragraph   , framework implemented entirety manner manages strengthens ’ engagement non-State actors towards attainment public health objectives , including multistakeholder partnerships , whilst protecting preserving ’ integrity , independence , credibility reputation ;    . Director-General , application framework , responding acute public health events described International Health Regulations (      ) emergencies health consequences , act according Constitution  principles identified framework . , Director-General may exercise flexibility might needed application procedures framework responses , he/she deems necessary , accordance ’ responsibilities health cluster lead , need engage quickly broadly non-State actors coordination , scale _________   Including Article   ( ) Constitution World Health Organization .          BASIC DOCUMENTS service delivery  . Director-General inform Member States appropriate means ,   including particular written communication , without undue delay response requires exercise flexibility , include summary information justification use flexibility annual report engagement non-State actors . BASIC DOCUMENTS POLICY OPERATIONAL PROCEDURES ENGAGEMENT ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS   . policy regulates specifically ’ engagement academic institutions type interaction .   provisions overarching framework also apply engagements academic institutions .   . engagement academic institutions institutional level distinguished collaboration individual experts working academic institutions . PARTICIPATION Participation academic institutions meetings  . invite academic institutions participate consultations , hearings meetings accordance paragraph    overarching framework . Consultations hearings electronic person .   . Participation meetings basis discussion item academic institution particular interest participation adds value deliberations meeting . participation exchange information views , never formulation advice .   . nature participation academic institution depends type meeting concerned . format , modalities , participation academic institution consultations , hearings , meetings decided case-by-case basis governing bodies Secretariat . Participation inputs received academic institutions shall made publicly available , wherever possible . Academic institutions take part decision-making process Organization . Involvement Secretariat meetings organized academic institutions  . organize joint meetings , cosponsor meetings organized academic institutions , long integrity , independence reputation Organization preserved , long participation furthers ’ objectives expressed General Programme Work . staff members may participate meetings organized academic institutions accordance Organization ’ internal rules . _________   See paragraphs   –   overarching framework five types interaction .      FRAMEWORK ENGAGEMENT NON-STATE ACTORS     academic institution shall misrepresent ’ participation official support , endorsement , meeting , shall agree use ’ participation promotional purposes . Specific policies operational procedures   . participation meetings organized academic institutions co-organizers , cosponsors , panellists speakers shall managed according provisions framework . RESOURCES  . accept financial in-kind contributions academic institutions long contributions fall within ’ General Programme Work , create conflicts interest , managed accordance framework , comply relevant regulations , rules policies . resources institution academic   . provide implementation particular work ( research , clinical trial , laboratory work preparation document ) , accordance Financial Regulations Financial Rules applicable rules policies . either project institution considers merits support , based clear public health interest , consistent ’ General Programme Work , project organized coordinated . former constitutes grant , latter service . Specific policies operational procedures    . acceptance resources academic institution handled accordance provisions framework relevant rules guidelines Staff Regulations Staff Rules , Financial Regulations Financial Rules policies governing procurement , well ’ guidelines medicine donations ’ guidelines health care equipment donations ;    . reasons transparency , contributions academic institutions must publicly acknowledged accordance policies practices .    . Acknowledgements shall usually worded along following lines : “ World Health Organization gratefully acknowledges financial contribution [ academic institution ] towards [ description outcome activity ] ” .          BASIC DOCUMENTS    . Contributions received academic institutions listed financial report audited financial statements well Programme budget web portal register non-State actors .    . Academic institutions may use fact made contribution materials used commercial , promotional , marketing advertisement purposes. Geneva : World Health Organization ;      : pp .    –    .       FINANCIAL REGULATIONS WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION  Regulation – Applicability Delegation Authority  .  Regulations shall govern financial administration World Health Organization .  .  Director-General responsible ensuring effective financial administration Organization accordance Regulations .  .  Without prejudice Regulation  .  Director-General may delegate writing officers Organization authority related accountability considers necessary effective implementation Regulations .  .  Director-General shall establish Financial Rules , including relevant guidelines limits implementation Regulations , order ensure effective financial administration , exercise economy , safeguard assets Organization . Regulation II – Financial Period  .  financial period programme budget shall two consecutive calendar years beginning even-numbered year . Regulation III – Budget  .  budget estimates financial period , referred Article    Constitution ( hereinafter referred “ budget proposals ” ) , shall prepared Director-General . budget proposals shall presented United States dollars .  .  budget proposals shall divided parts , sections chapters , shall include information , annexes explanatory statements may requested , behalf , Health Assembly annexes statements Director-General may deem necessary useful . _________   Text adopted Fifty-third World Health Assembly amended Fifty-eighth , Sixtieth , Sixty-second , Sixty-fourth Sixty-sixth World Health Assemblies ( resolutions WHA  .  , WHA  .   , WHA  .  , WHA  .  , WHA  .   WHA  .  ) . Previous text adopted Fourth World Health Assembly ( resolution WHA .   ) amended Thirteenth , Eighteenth , Twenty-fifth , Twenty-sixth , Twenty-ninth , Thirtieth , Thirty-third , Thirty-seventh , Forty-first , Forty-fourth , Forty-eighth World Health Assemblies ( resolutions WHA  .   , WHA  .   , WHA  .   , WHA  .   , WHA  .   , WHA  .   , WHA  .   , WHA  .  , WHA  .   , WHA  .   , WHA  .   , decision WHA   (    ) ) . –     –     BASIC DOCUMENTS  .
